text.p: Germany's Bayerische Vereinsbank AG expects a substantial rise in operating profits in 1997 amid modest global economic growth, its management board chairman Albrecht Schmidt said on Thursday.

In a speech prepared for delivery at a news conference, Schmidt said: "With four percent growth in the global economy and a slight economic recovery in Germany ... I am viewing Vereinsbank's future with optimism."
"Thus I expect a substantial increase in operating profit for 1997. Net interest income should rise in mortgage business and in banking business," Schmidt said.
In its annual report, which was released on Thursday, the bank also said it would not need to make a significant hike in risk provisions in 1997, despite difficult economic conditions.

"The provisions we have made so far and our improved risk control should protect us from a significant increase in our risk provisions, despite the ongoing difficult economic situation and continued rise in insolvencies," the report said.
Vereinsbank's risk provisions fell to 704 million marks from 721 million in 1996.
Schmidt also added that Vereinsbank, a mortgage specialist, would struggle to match the strong growth in commission income it achieved in 1996, even if markets remained favourable.

Vereinsbank reported a 14.1 percent rise in commission income to 1.2 billion marks in 1996. Its operating profit, after risk provisions of 704 million marks, advanced 18.4 percent to 1.64 billion marks.
Net profit, released for the first time on Thursday, advanced 32.3 percent to 869 million marks.
Schmidt also forecast an improvement in own-account trading profits in 1997, partly because Vereinsbank had expanded its international trading activities.
Net income from own-account trading in 1996 fell to 254 million marks from 270 million.
Costs would increase only because of added spending, "to expand our competitive positions and improve our profitability," Schmidt said.
